name: Justin Welsh
subtitle: Building my one-person business to $10M in revenue. Posts and articles about the process.
about: Over the last decade, I helped build two companies past a $1B valuation and raise over $300M in venture capital. Then, in 2019, I burned out.So, I decided to walk away from my high-paying executive job.But, before I could, I had a hypothesis.I believed building an audience online would be an incredible asset. That attention was the new currency and would play a major part in my success as an entrepreneur.So, I started building my brand on LinkedIn in early 2019. And the results were pretty phenomenal.In just 6 months I grew from zero followers to over 20,000.And on August 1st of 2019, I walked away from my executive role at a fast-growing startup.Since that day, I've spent my time building a number of one-person Internet businesses.My mission is to be the "Diversified Solopreneur." posts.post: Here are 12 powerful pieces of advice I'd give to aspiring internet entrepreneurs.  1. There is a business idea in your practical work experience, but also in the things you are obsessed with. Lean in.  2. Your unique value proposition is key to your success. Why should someone choose you over all of the people out there? (more here: https://lnkd.in/eX27xCZG)  3. Distribution is your best friend. If you can't share you message effectively, you're going to struggle.  4. Create content you enjoy creating, not what you think is "best". Like to write? Write. Like video? Record. Consistency is what matters, so you'd better like it.  5. Create systems and frameworks for turning your ideas into creative pieces of content that people will enjoy. No systems? Gonna be tough. (more here: https://lnkd.in/eGAABFwX)  6. Build for the long-term. Rather than trying to generate a ton of revenue right from the start, think about under-promising, under-pricing, and over-delivering. That early trust will pay off in the long run.  7. The more niche you are, the more you can sell products and services. The more broad you are, the more creative you'll have to get.  8. You become really good when you understand who you're serving, what you're helping them do, and what outcome they can expect. This becomes your content language. (more here: https://lnkd.in/eiwMuH3W)  9. You become great when you analyze everything you're doing, and form hypotheses about what's working and what isn't.  10. You become excellent when you take action against those hypotheses until you solve the problems.  11. Business is never "done". You're either moving forward or getting worse. The default mode in entrepreneurship is reverse.  12. Automation is the great differentiator. If your revenue can be generated by content and email sequences that work when you're sleeping, you'll be tough to beat.  Hope these are helpful.  Would love to hear some of your best advice.  If you enjoyed these, please reshare it to your timeline ‚ôªÔ∏è

posts.post: Working for yourself is really hard.  It often involves:  1. Wrestling with self-doubt, questioning if you're cut out for this.  2. Battling impostor syndrome, feeling like you don‚Äôt belong.  3. Juggling multiple responsibilities, trying to keep all balls in the air.  4. Navigating financial challenges, which can be scary as hell.  Yes, it's hard.  But truth be told, every path is hard.  So pause...and give yourself some time to think:  Are the challenges you're working on in your current career fulfilling?  If the answer is no, it's never too late to build something new. Something small that may, someday, be something big.  Today is the perfect time to embrace change and choose the 'right hard' for your journey.  Are you?  If so, read this: https://lnkd.in/eYC-5JcC

posts.post: 'Big Company' priorities:  - Job title - Quota attainment - Salary + commission - Number of direct reports - What co-workers think of you  Solopreneur priorities:  - Health - Network - Free time - Creativity - Time with family - Location independence  A beautiful shift.  In business we're taught to 'maximize' everything:  - Our profits - Our career growth - Our shareholder value - How much money we make  In Solopreneurship, it's the opposite.  It's not about getting more.  It's about having enough.  If that sounds good, do what I did:  1. Reflect on your values and aspirations. 2. Identify your business goals. 3. Evaluate your current situation. 4. Define your 'enough'.  Here's how: https://lnkd.in/e6DbPFvi

comments.author: Justin Welsh
comments.comment: Side note: There is nothing wrong with working for a company, big or small. It's just always good to remember that profit is the primary driver of nearly everything. When you work for yourself (yes, it's hard) you can choose to continue driving for profit only...or you can choose to focus on building a high-quality life and then figuring out how to support that with enough profit. No wrong choice. Just different.
